description: Great and nice waiters and staff. Nice decor and ambience but a bit on the noisy side. Pricey drinks with hardly any alcohol in them. Pricey food and small portions. Great videos of Grace Jones circa 1980. Don't bother to order the kale salad, save your money, and just rake some dried leaves from your garden, add some toasted almonds, some slivers of red onions, a dash of balsamic vinegar and at a fraction of the cost, you've killed 2 birds with one stone and made yourself a salad of dried leaves to chew on forever and exfoliate your gums too at the same time! While dinning in a restaurant, nothing's more ANNOYING than meat with bones in it. There should be a global law that no restaurant is allowed to serve meat with bones in it. Who wants to pick through meat & bones and accidentally break their teeth while biting on a piece of bone and then sue the business for dental work? Me me!
author: Marc N.

description: I've dined at Kaya on 2 separate occasions while visiting SF. The food is amazing. The 1st time I got the Piri Piri Chicken. On my 2nd visit, I ordered the Oxtails. The meat was falling off of the bones. I'm not a fan of shrimp and even that was delicious. I'd like to add that yuca is a favorite of mine and the way that they prepared it was better than most Jamaican or Peruvian eateries in North Carolina. I can't wait to visit again. This is a great place to have a date night or enjoy an evening roundtable with friends.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
A friend and I met at Kaya for a quick, early dinner before a performance at the ballet. It's a beautiful space and got crowded quickly. The bar is lively and well-stocked. The ceilings are high so, although it's pretty noisy, the noise isn't at all bothersome. The crowd is young, energetic, fun. And the service is great, we loved our server.

The food though is pretty mediocre. I had a ginger rum drink that was kinda tasteless, served in a small metal cup with lots of ice... there couldn't have been more than half a shot of rum in the drink. A small piece of grilled salmon (the fish was fresh, but there was nothing special about the flavor) with a very small quantity of slightly-burned roasted cauliflower and brussel sprouts was $29, which is in my book pretty ridiculous. The jerk chicken was very impressive-looking and had good flavor, but it was overcooked and dry. We passed on the dessert.

The restaurant's location puts it close to Twitter & Uber headquarters and, as I said, it's a handsome place so I suspect there will be plenty of customers who won't mind the prices, it'll probably do well. But eventually, Kaya will probably need to get their acts together and put more effort into making good food. If their prices were more reasonable, I'd return and wait it out. As it is, I can pick up a comparable piece of salmon and grille it myself for around $4-$5. And I won't burn the vegetables.

By the way, heads up: The restaurant adds 18% to the bill for gratuity, even for a party of two. Caveat emptor.
author: John M.

description: Kaya was a pleasant surprise!! Delicious brunch. Fun waiters. Boozey drinks. Ideal Sunday spot.
author: Chinae G.

description: My wife and I went to Kaya with another couple last night. Although we enjoyed the novelty of Jamaican food, my wife and I decided that one visit was sufficient. First, as others have commented, the background music--really foreground music--is loud, so it's not a place where conversation is easy. The design of the restaurant, however, is inviting and very chic, with a tall wall of liquors providing the backdrop. Now to the food: all of us agreed that it was tasty! The portion sizes vary, however. My wife's piri-piri chicken was a half bird with plenty of meat and accompaniments. My goat curry was bony, as goat tends to be, so there really was very little meat; I would have been hungry if I were not able to finish off the chicken that my wife couldn't eat. The curried vegetables ordered by one friend was ample enough that he took some home. The grilled wild gulf shrimp ordered by the other friend was billed as a small eat, but she had trouble consuming it because it was so spicy. We all  sampled the salt fish fritters, which some of us really liked and others not so much. Likewise, we shared a slice of Jamaican black cake, which was very dense with hints of rum that reminded us of a Christmas cake. Two of us consumed most of it, with the others satisfied by a small bite. My wife really enjoyed her pomegranate mint soda, but my spicy ginger beer really didn't taste very gingery or spicy at all. I'd opt for the mint soda. All in all, it wasn't a bad experience, but considering the prices of the big plates, we felt that the value wasn't there. There are lots of restaurants in San Francisco and this one deserves a try, but like us, you may find that a single visit is just fine.
author: William L.

description:
I knocked off one star because the food took a while and the sides that came with the entrees weren't proportioned that well. 

I got the cod salt fish fritters, plantains, pili pili chicken, oxtail, and spicy ginger beer. 

I can skip the fritters next time around. $13 for 3 pieces and just not my favorite. 

The rest was cooked extremely well and flavors were on point. Just needed a bigger portion for the sides to match the entree. 

Ambiance is fun and nice. Dimmed lighting and nice decor. I'll be back! Service was extremely friendly, I was impressed!
author: Daisy S.

description: Our server was super energetic and fun. Not the most attentive, but made up for it with his great attitude. There were four of us for dinner. We ordered 2 cocktails and one rum punch at happy hour price plus two starters, two entrees and the three desserts and it came out close to $100/person. The food was flavorful, but not very substantial. The entrees had way more rice/rice and beans than meat, so it was not really good for sharing. I thought the menu was pretty overpriced for what we got.
author: La Tache T.

description: Oxtail stew and Curry goat were amazingly delicious and exactly what we were craving for. We had originally called around 5pm to check if we could make a RSVP and they stated the earliest would be 9:30pm. We decided not to rsvp since we weren't sure if we could wait that long. The person on the phone did add that the bar was available if there was any seats available when we got there. We ended up getting there after 9 and we ended up getting a table right away. Enjoyed the music and atmosphere. I love plantains and had to order more. Customer service from everyone we talked to was friendly. Definitely a place I'd go again! Especially for that punch with rum...
author: Trisha P.

description: The cocktails are amazing! It's like a fruit and vegetable alcohol extraordinary creation! You have to try them there. Great food, vibe, service. Lengthy wait however this is SF so if you want someplace that's good it willl be crowded.
author: Laurence S.

description: Everything about this place makes me wish I still worked across the street from it. The ambiance, the staff (thanks for the amazing service Langston), the food was delicious, the rum was delicious. I recommend the saltfish fritters, caramelized carrots and squash, plantains, goat curry, jerk chicken salad, oxtails, Jamaican black cake, and spiced vanilla soft serve, which was our entire order. I will definitely be back. My suggestion is to make reservations as this place is popular. My other suggestion is to treat yourself to the wide assortment of rum they have.
author: Lemuel Y.

description:
Amazing food, amazing people! I loved everything we had especially the potatoes and chicken sandwich. The fries are seasoned with thyme!

The space itself is well apportioned and has plenty of lighting. They also have a great happy hour that I'd recommend to anyone!
author: Mical C.

description: Awesome brunch spot and can't wait to go back for dinner!  My friend and I split the salt fritters, jerk chicken salad, and jamaican sampler (must do).  All delicious - and the service was so great.  Our waiter helped us select the right mix and amount of food.  We also got to try several cocktails - and the pitcher of mimosa is a total value play.  Passion fruit mimosas were delightful.  Quiet enough to have a conversation where you can hear one another - even with a full room of people.
author: Laura W.

description:
I was extremely excited to check out Kaya after reading the Purewow article of best new restaurants in the city. The service was fantastic! Our waiter was extremely kind and did not push us at all. He checked in appropriately to make sure things were going well and the flow of food coming out of the kitchen was at the right pace. 

However, we were unfortunately very disappointed with the food. The black pepper tofu was very dry and sweet and the jasmine rice was mushy. The grilled wild gulf shrimp tasted like the shrimp was frozen and had a mealy texture. The fried plantains were flavorful. I think they dehydrated the roasted kale and beet salad. I would have preferred thick chunks of beets. It was bad, but it also didn't hit the spot for me. The Mary's organic jerk chicken (big eats) was dry. I coated the chicken in their hot sauces so I can't speak to the jerk flavoring, but the meat itself was too dry. The rice and peas were enjoyable.

Overall, I have to say I would much prefer going to Cha Cha Cha for Jamaican food. I am grateful for the kind service, but the food was underwhelming. I expected more and left disappointed. I wish them the best and hope they continue to improve.
author: Emma L.

description: I had a great meal here.  The service was amazing and the food was excellent.  I plan to visit again
author: Nicole M.

description:
Great food.  Great service.
We split the Kale and Beet salad and the Tofu dish to start (it was difficult to pick just two).  Both were excellent and the portions were pretty big for starters.  I had the Jerk Chicken which was also very tasty (as you can read in many of the reviews).  We tried a few of the cocktails - they were all good but I wouldn't call out any of them as a favorite.
The service was perfect - I felt like they had the right balance of checking in frequently enough to make sure you didn't need anything but not so often that your dinner conversation was interrupted.
author: Danielle T.

description:
Kaya replaces AltaCa which has really amazing burgers in our neighborhood; but, once I heard Kaya was Jamaican, I was super excited to support. My first visit I had the Patties and Jerk Chicken Salad. Everything was so yummy! 

The second time, I ordered the Jerk Chicken salad again. Two issues that will not deter me from stepping into the restaurant ever again: 

1. Instead of a proper piece of chicken, the salad had no proper pieces of chicken and instead was full of very small chicken scraps that included bones. Very disappointing for a $19 salad.

2. The salad was too spicy! I can take spice; but, it would be more palatable if Kaya considered adding a cooling element, even if it's just on the side.
author: Charlie D.

description: Tried the curried vegetables and the jerk chicken. Both were great and very flavourful! Service was super fast, and the ambience and decor were very nice. Will definitely go back to try the small plates and cocktails!
author: Divya S.

description: This is a great place, it's near both Muni and Bart and the service is very friendly.  The food is good and while the drinks don't seem to be included for Happy Hour they're good too.
author: a f.

description: Great vibes when you walk in. Really good drinks and good food. Horrible service. Our server seemed ok at first, but when the food arrived, he handed me the wrong order and just walked away. I waved three times to get his attention and for a restaurant not that big, anyone would have noticed me waving. My boyfriend got up and told him he brought me the wrong order and all he said back to him was "ok". Being a server for almost five years while I was in undergrad, the first thing I would've have done was apologize and assure the correct order will come out shortly. I don't mind the mistake at all, everyone makes a mistake, it is how he handled it. We were ignored pretty much the whole night until I he sensed how I upset I was from the whole situation. To my surprise, he also automatically charged us 20% tip. From my understanding, that is only automatically applied with a big group of more than 5 or 6, but not two. I was so excited to try this place, but after tonight, I will certainly not go back to this place again. What a disappointment.
author: Ingrid C.

description: It was kind of just meh for the price. I had a tofu dish for brunch and the tofu was cold, hard, and dry. The fried plantains were okay. You'd be better off to try to find a hole in the wall soul food place. The drink I had was pretty nasty too and didn't align with the description.
author: Rachel M.

description: good happy hour spot.  the apps were reasonably priced, and the portions were pretty big!  i particularly liked the papaya salad, fries (which comes w/ regular potato and sweet potato), plantains and the salt fish fritters.  our salmon entree was also tasty.  the jerk chicken was only ok, so i don't know if i would order it again.
author: Helen T.

description: The food was fine but overpriced IMO.  Wife got the Jamaican breakfast.  She liked it and said the salt fish tasted Filipino.  The cassava home fries were good, but the fried dumplings were plain and nothing to write home about.  Fried plantains are always good (hard to mess up).  I got the jerk chicken sandwich.  It was also good but there was very little meat in it, about 3 chicken nuggets worth.  The rest was slaw or fried plantains.  Now I like slaw and plantains so it tasted fine, but for $19 I expect more meat.  Also, the papaya salad was mostly greens and 3 tiny pieces of papaya, so I thought that was a little misleading.  So decent not amazing food, but overpriced.
author: John K.

description: Was very excited to try this place as it was listed in an article on San Francisco's trending restaurants. Grew up with Jamaican home cooking and this was certainly no where near close. The vibe and cocktails (ginger shandy and rum punch) were fine. The entrees we ordered were the jerk chicken and the goat curry both were obviously previously prepared, they came out not to long after we ordered and before the cocktails. The food was mediocre at best and over $20+ per entree, not worth it.
author: Tania V.

description: It's my first time here and I'm a little disappointed. The ambiance is really nice- music not too loud. However, jerk chicken doesn't worth $24 . It was spicier than I expected (comparing to other carribean restaurants around bay area) and there was nothing special with the chicken.
author: Gokce K.

description: A very nice break from the usual California fusion options and tired menus. Everything we ordered was delicious, but my favorite part of the experience was the service. Lovely, attentive staff who genuinely care about your experience. Go!
author: Osanna A.

description: I have always enjoyed the flavors of Jamaican cuisine but have found the execution to be imperfect -- dry chicken, overwhelming spice etc.  Kaya evades those traps with perfect execution and yummy inventive cuisine. Dungeness crab with black pepper sauce may not be a traditional Jamaican dish, but the flavors speak of the island and the crab is moist and perfectly cooked.  Great service and tasty cocktails round out the experience nicely.
author: Peter H.

description: All you need to know is that fried plantains are delicious and the staff is super helpful and friendly.
author: Jeff B.

description: This place has a great ambiance but everything else went downhill from there. Overpriced and underwhelming. Never had such small portions of Jamaican food not traditional at all and catering to the millennial techs who probably have never been outside the USA. Got the fried plantain, oxtail stew. Left hungry and felt like my money would have gotten more worth at Sweet Fingers, Coconuts and other Scotch Bonnet. Even his former restaurant Kingston 11 gives better portions and flavor. There drinks were a hit and had more flavor. Unfortunately I won't be back along with the other 6 of us who arrived excited but left disappointed. The stars given were for ambiance and cocktails. No stars for food.
author: KK M.

description: Really excellent, innovative food. We loved everything we ordered, especially the kale and beet salad. Pretty overpriced, especially the cocktails, but all around great dining experience.
author: Hali H.

description: Good music, decor, and drinks. Food was okay. A service charge is added to your bill, but when we asked a server, he was very unclear. His explanation sounded like we were supposed to tip on top of that fee (which we did since we didn't want to short the server any money) but I don't think that's correct.
author: Tina L.

description: I'm not one to leave reviews but I had to do it for this place or more specifically around their service. If you go there ask for Oleg. He is their bartender extraordinaire! He does great cocktails and is so friendly, I wasn't too sure what to get from the drinks menu and asked him to invent a cocktail with some bubbles and here it was..... bubble heaven! The food is tasty and portions are decent- i was very impressed by the speed of service there too. All together a great place to go with friends, unwind, have bites, refreshing drinks and great company! Definitely on my top 10!
author: Hadi L.
